entry.title: How does the official start date impact employee benefits calculation?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I‚Äôve been researching how to properly calculate end-of-service benefits, particularly in scenarios where there‚Äôs a contract signing date and a visa-stamping / work-permit activation date.

Contract signed: Jan 2018 Visa stamped / legal work authorization: March 2018 Last working day: Feb 2021 My question: Which date should generally be used as the ‚Äúofficial start date‚Äù for benefits/gratuity calculations under UAE law the contract signing or visa stamping?

I know in some jurisdictions only the visa/permit date matters; but are there SAP customers/implementers who have encountered payroll configurations or HR modules where contract date was used (if support documents exist)?

For those who might want to check or confirm, I found this online tool helpful:https://calculategratuity.ae/ it takes start date, contract type, end date and calculates gratuity according to UAE labour law. Might be useful to compare values.

Thanks in advance for any references to legal texts, experiences, or recommendations on how SAP HR systems should be configured in these cases.

entry.title: Re: Difference between TYPE and LIKE in ABAP ‚Äì When to us...
entry.content:
Just for your information: If you are new to SAP ABAP or the SAP ecosystem, it is highly recommended to first refer to the official SAP documentation: SAP ABAP Documentation. Before posting questions, please also try searching on Google, the SAP Community, or even tools like ChatGPT, as many answers are already available. This helps you learn faster and ensures questions are more focused.

However, please answer below.

1.  TYPE 

Declare a variable based on a data type (built-in or DDIC type). 

Syntax:

DATA var TYPE abap_type [LENGTH len] [DECIMALS dec] [VALUE val] [READ-ONLY].

Eg:

 

DATA text TYPE string VALUE 'Text'.
DATA count TYPE i VALUE 1.
DATA price TYPE p LENGTH 8 DECIMALS 2 VALUE '1.99'.

2 LIKE  

Declare a variable based on another variable or table/field.

  • LIKE copies the type and attributes of another variable or data object.

  • Useful to create new variables similar to existing ones.

Syntax:

 

DATA var LIKE existing_var_or_field [VALUE val] [READ-ONLY].

Eg:

DATA wa TYPE scarr. " Work area based on DDIC table SCARR
SELECT SINGLE * FROM scarr INTO @wa WHERE carrid = 'BA'.
DATA buffer LIKE wa. " Another variable with same type as wa buffer = wa.

Comparison 

Feature TYPE LIKE
Refers toType definition (DDIC or ABAP)Existing variable/field
Updates if DDIC changesYesOnly if referencing the field
Recommended forIn most cases, future-proofCopying existing variables
ExampleDATA lv_value TYPE i.DATA lv_temp LIKE lv_value.

Note:

Always use TYPE for work areas of tables (from DDIC)

Try to avoid LIKE as much as possible 

Eg:

DATA gt_scarr TYPE TABLE OF scarr. " Correct
DATA wa_scarr LIKE LINE OF gt_scarr. " Work area based on table

entry.title: Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in 3-system‚ÄØlandscape.
entry.content:
Embarking on the 3-System Landscape (SL) journey in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can be overwhelming. A newly provisioned test tenant may not operate efficiently unless it contains sufficient known data to support you best with testing and validations. 

To address this challenge and accelerate test tenant readiness, SAP has introduced two strategic options, namely TEST DATA CONVERSION and TEST DATA REFRESH. These features are designed to accelerate tenant readiness by simplify data handling and thereby enhancing overall system efficiency. 

In this blog, we‚Äôll take a high-level look at the 3-SL and explore how TEST DATA CONVERSION and TEST DATA REFRESH facilitate to a smoother, faster, and reliable test environment setup. 

 

3-SL  

As part of your strategic transformation, you are planning to migrate from a 2-SL to a 3-SL in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This transition is aimed at enhancing system governance, improving testing capabilities, and enabling a clear change management process. Before diving into the data migration services, let‚Äôs examine the landscape differences between the current 2-SL setup and the target 3-SL setup to understand the value and impact of this shift.  

 As part of the 3-SL conversion in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, a new test tenant is introduced to support robust validation and quality assurance. However, at the time of conversion, this tenant is provisioned as an empty tenant, with no data (transactional or master data) available. To make this test tenant fully functional and efficient, it must be filled with the essential fuel that drives all meaningful testing, which is nothing but valid data. 

As the saying goes, ‚ÄúData is the new fuel‚Äù and without it, even the most advanced SL cannot deliver value to its fullest. Populating the test tenant with relevant, valid, and consistent data is critical to make the test tenant valuable and ensure a smooth transition to production tenants. 

Now that we understand the importance of data in powering the test tenant, the next step is to determine how to introduce this data effectively into test tenants.

 

Manual Data Uploads: A Time-Consuming Process 

While manual data uploads are technically possible using SAP Fiori apps, templates, or others. but they involve significant drawbacks: 

  • High Effort: Manually preparing valid data and uploading data comes at the cost of extensive time and resources.  
  • Cumbersome Process: This process itself will be complex and challenging as multiple tools and formats need to be used and the complexity increases with large data volumes. 
  • Delayed Availability: Test tenant will not be available for business use until the manual data upload is completed, there by blocking the testing activities for the released objects.

We have seen that, manual data entry is not ideal for large volume of data upload and accelerating tenant readiness. 

 

Embracing Automation: Smarter Ways to Populate Your Test Tenant 

We‚Äôre in the era of automation and manual data entry is no longer a viable option for efficient system setup. If you already have rich, validated data in your customizing tenant and production tenant, the question becomes: 
How can you use this data to build a clean, depersonalized, and test-ready environment in your new test tenant. To address this common pain point, SAP has introduced two specialized services designed to simplify and accelerate the process: 

  • TEST DATA CONVERSION ‚Äì post-conversion accelerator 
  • TEST DATA REFRESH ‚Äì Ongoing quality assurance 

 

To streamline the setup of a new test tenant, SAP offers two powerful services that cater to different data sources and testing needs: 

 TEST DATA CONVERSION Service ‚Äì post-conversion accelerator 

  • Purpose: Transfers configuration and application data from the Customizing Tenant to the New Test Tenant. 
  • Goal: Ensures the new test system is available seamlessly and without issues, reflecting the latest customizing setup. 
  • Source System: Customizing Tenant 
  • Target System: New Test Tenant 

This service is ideal for scenarios where you want to validate configurations, execute test cases, test new features based on your previous customizing tenant. 

 

 TEST DATA REFRESH Service ‚Äì Ongoing quality assurance 

  • Purpose: Transfers selected business data from the Production Tenant to the New Test Tenant. 
  • Goal: Ensures the new test system is populated with production-like test data, enabling realistic testing and ongoing quality assurance. 
  • Source System: Production Tenant 
  • Target System: New Test Tenant 

This service is perfect for regression testing, integration validation, and performance benchmarking using real-world data.

 

What‚Äôs Next? 

In this blog, we explored the two key services TEST DATA CONVERSION and TEST DATA REFRESH that help populate a new test tenant efficiently. We also clarified the source and target systems for each service along with their roles in test tenant setup. 

In the next blog, we‚Äôll take a deep dive into the TEST DATA CONVERSION service, examining its capabilities, process flow, and how it ensures a seamless transition from the customizing tenant to the test tenant. Stay tuned to uncover configuration tips, and real-world use cases that make TEST DATA CONVERSION a game-changer for test system readiness. 

 

Reference links: 

Blogs:
  • 3SL Conversion for two-system landscape customers managed by SAP Central Business Configuration
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3SL onboarding and initial system set-up series
  • Streamlining 3SL Post Conversion Steps: Introducing CIAS and TDC Services
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/test-data-refresh-service-request-on-sap-for-me/ba-p/14171893

Community Pages:

  • https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/s4hana-cloud/three-system-landscape

entry.title: Re: ROLE AUTHORIZATION PFCG
entry.content: One of the roles assigned to USER1 has authorisation object S_TABU_DIS with wide display rights. SE16 can be restricted by table (S_TABU_NAM), but also by table authorisation group (S_TABU_DIS). The check order is that if S_TABU_DIS fails, only then is S_TABU_NAM checked. S_TABU_DIS with * is a critical authorisation based on the SAP Security Baseline Template.

entry.title: Synchronizing ERP Vendor IDs and SM IDs Between SAP Ariba and Multiple ERPs
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

I am currently working on an integration scenario involving SAP Ariba Supplier Management and multiple SAP ERPs via CIG (Cloud Integration Gateway), and I would like to get your expert input on the best approach to fulfill a specific client requirement.

Context and Requirement:
The customer wants to ensure that new suppliers are always created starting from SAP Ariba Network. Once a supplier is registered and qualified in Ariba, the goal is to maintain a single ERP Vendor ID and one SM ID across the landscape.

The main objectives are:

  • Avoiding double maintenance of suppliers across systems.
  • Ensuring a consistent relationship between one SM ID in Ariba and one ERP Vendor ID in the connected ERP systems.
  • Preventing a scenario where one supplier in Ariba has one SM ID but two different ERP Vendor IDs (which, to my knowledge, is not supported).

Possible Approach Considered:

  • Supplier is created in Ariba with an SM ID.
  • A temporary vendor ID (e.g., VDRxxx) is generated and routed via CIG to both ERPs.
  • At the registration approval stage, the integration to ERP 1 provides the final ERP Vendor ID.
  • The open question: Can this final ERP Vendor ID also be pushed automatically to ERP 2 via CIG so that both ERPs share the same vendor ID for the supplier?

One possible design that comes to mind would be to allow the supplier to be initially created in Ariba with its SM ID and a temporary vendor ID, for example VDRxxx. In this initial phase, the information could be routed via CIG to both ERPs. The point of uncertainty arises when the supplier reaches the stage of registration approval: if the first ERP integration returns a final ERP Vendor ID, could this same vendor ID then be pushed and synchronized also to the second ERP? In other words, is there a standard mechanism within CIG and Ariba Supplier Management to enforce the use of a single ERP Vendor ID across multiple ERPs, or would this require a different design approach?

Final Questions:

  1. Is the above scenario feasible with standard Ariba‚ÄìCIG capabilities?
  2. If not, what would be the recommended best practice to ensure alignment between ERP Vendor IDs and SM IDs across multiple ERPs?
  3. Considering an architecture of 1 parent and 1 child (buying and invoicing), what is the most reliable approach to avoid duplicate supplier maintenance while maintaining consistent identifiers?

Thank you for your help and support!

entry.title: Re: How many licenses needed for SAP Adaptive Enterprise...
entry.content:
Hello Sergio

The number of licenses required would be 32. 

Please refer to https://support.sap.com/en/my-support/keys/license-key-help.html

(I had an issue with this direct link which may have to do with SAP Portal, if so use navigation
On SAP Portal, go to 'Keys' tile
Then expand Licene Key help (click on > before it)
Link to 'License Key help'
Use 'SAP Sybase' tab
There is an FAQ 'What is number of licenses'

The number of licenses to be specified depends on how many licensed units are needed for the application running on this machine. For entitlements licensed under CPU license types, the quantity should correspond to the number of processors, i.e. cores, on the machine, partition or resource-set.

Support KBA also covers this:
https://me.sap.com/notes/3143614 SYSAM core licenses requirement when hyper-threading is enabled - SAP ASE

Kind regards

Bart

entry.title: Re: How can we resend the emails from IAS
entry.content:
So in case someone is just dealing with this in the context of bulk importing via csv:
urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User:sendMail can be used as attribute in csv-file and set to true.

So deleting new users and re-importing with sendMail attribute is a way, without using manual password-reset button/mail.

Obviously, this is not quite the same context as a general resend button, and i also assume people already know. Also this should only be used for new users with no linked app-data or anything.

entry.title: Re: ABAP SALV Table with Checkbox Column, Select/Deselect All, and Email Export Functionality
entry.content:
Why did you code the selection yourself instead of using the standard one?

gr_table->get_selections( )->set_selection_mode( cl_salv_selections=>multiple ).

Using IF_SALV_C_SELECTION_MODE~MULTIPLE for modern selection of lines (click anywhere in the table) and IF_SALV_C_SELECTION_MODE~ROW_COLUMN for classical selection of lines (with checkboxes)

entry.title: Understanding the Distinct Scope of SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
As organisations evaluate deployment options for their ERP systems, SAP Cloud ERP Private are often compared without taking the full scope of services into account. Yet, its unique architecture and comprehensive service model make direct comparisons challenging - and frequently misleading.

Traditional comparisons tend to overlook many of the embedded services that come standard with SAP Cloud ERP Private and ignore many of the available options, inadvertently giving other deployment models an apparent advantage. This not only skews perception but also obscures the full value SAP delivers out of the box.

To bring clarity to this discussion, we highlight the key services included in SAP Cloud ERP Private . Our goal is to empower customers with a clear understanding of what they receive, helping them make informed decisions based on a complete picture.

Modernise your ERP system while retaining your investment

SAP aims to transition all customers using SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA by 2027. Before the introduction of RISE with SAP in 2021, SAP did not fully meet the needs of customers seeking cloud-based ERP solutions. The primary option available was S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, which required a new implementation. This was not a viable option for many existing SAP ERP customers who wanted to retain their investment in their current systems, leverage existing data, and carry forward customizations and modifications.

To address this gap, SAP introduced SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions with the launch of RISE with SAP. These single-tenant solutions offer each customer their own dedicated instance of SAP software, hosted on separate infrastructure within a data center operated by one of the major hyperscalers or SAP itself. Existing SAP ERP customers can choose to either lift-and-shift their SAP ERP systems or transition to SAP Cloud ERP Private using a system conversion, selective data transition, or a new implementation approach.

With SAP Cloud ERP Private, SAP is taking away the complexity of designing, building and operating SAP software for our customers. We're doing this by providing a user or metric-based subscription model that includes the software and tooling license, infrastructure and technical managed services - everything that you need to run an SAP solution.

SAP Design, Build and Operate the entire SAP technical solution stack

SAP Enterprise Cloud Services (ECS), the business unit in SAP who is responsible for design, build and operate of Cloud ERP Private, delivers a robust framework for operating SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions, combining infrastructure, software licensing, and technical managed services into a unified subscription model. This approach simplifies the complexity of running SAP systems in a private cloud while ensuring enterprise-grade performance, security, and compliance.

SAP ECS invests heavily in capabilities that ensure robust system design, rapid setup and delivery, and a high degree of automation for operational tasks. This section outlines the key activities performed by SAP ECS, categorized into three phases - Design, Build, and Operate.

The diagram below highlights the key cost elements covered in SAP Cloud ERP Private for the design, build and operation of SAP, while customers retain the responsibility and control of the application layer throughout the three phases. This is valid for every implementation and every time technical changes are made to the SAP system landscape, reducing technical tasks for customers so they can focus more on the business:

The SAP Cloud ERP Private service cover key cost elements for the setup and operation of SAP

The process of designing, building and operating SAP requires broad areas of technical expert competence and requires answers to many detailed technical questions necessary to make strong architecture design decisions. In SAP Cloud ERP Private, this complexity is moved away from being a customer responsibility to the responsibility of SAP and SAP will have the answers during the design, build and operate phases.

1. Design Phase

The primary goal of the Design phase activities is to define standard and configurable cloud-based architectures for SAP ERP systems that enable rapid deployment, customer choice to cater to their unique requirements and minimum manual overhead while meeting SAP‚Äôs stringent availability, Recovery Time Objective (RTO), and Recovery Point Objective (RPO), Service Level Agreements (SLAs), security and compliance standards. SAP ECS periodically reviews and refines these architectures and operational processes considering improvements in Hyperscaler infrastructure capabilities, 3rd party tools and services and SAP ECS‚Äôs own operational experience.

There are several complex topics that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • Which hyperscaler building blocks to use?
  • Which virtual machine instances are the right fit and certified by SAP?
  • What is the security design?
  • How can business continuity be achieved?
  • How should the systems be monitored?
  • How can resources be effectively scaled?
  • What is the architecture design?

Key activities performed by SAP ECS as part of the Design phase:

  • Reference Architectures: SAP collaborates with hyperscalers to define scalable, secure cloud architectures using SAP best practices.
  • Security & Compliance: Network isolation, encryption, intrusion detection, and adherence to ISO/NIST standards.
  • Monitoring & Incident Response System: Proactive incident response systems and tailored architecture advisory services ensure resilience and performance.
  • Cloud Architecture & Advisory: SAP collaborates with customers to define optimal technical architecture, considering each customer‚Äôs system sizing, cloud security, networking and technical integration, and business continuity requirements. SAP and customers jointly engage in a Technical Assessment process to ensure the non-functional requirements are met in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

For every SAP ERP customer moving to SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions, an SAP advisory team which is part of ECS (SAP Cloud Architecture & Advisory (CAA) which provides the above Cloud Architecture & Advisory services) or a similar partner advisory team, analyzes customer requirements and determines the best suitable configuration for the customer. By leveraging pre-defined standard and configurable cloud-based architectures defined by SAP, the time taken to define the architectures for each customer is significantly reduced and the decision process is simplified.

2. Build Phase

The primary goal of the Build phase activities is to define how to install, configure and validate the systems
that have been designed. There are several complex topics that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • Which tools should be used?
  • How to ensure systems are built to provide optimal performance?
  • How to migrate existing workloads?
  • How to ensure implementation best practices are followed?
  • How to reduce the deployment time?
  • How to technically validate the new infrastructure?
  • How to ensure proper governance to manage issues?

SAP has created a global framework for the build phase that spans the multi-cloud Infrastructure ecosystem.
This framework covers best practices for migration into the cloud, automated provisioning, deployment, and
validation of SAP systems. This allows our customers to safely adopt and run new SAP software innovations
because cloud services are tested and made production-ready before they are made available to customers.

  • Datacenter facilities, physical hardware and connectivity
  • Infrastructure Provisioning: Certified compute, storage, and network components are deployed using automated tools and DevOps methodologies.
  • Technical Managed Services required to build and deliver the infrastructure
  • Software Stack: SAP installs and configures OS, databases, and ERP applications, including industry best practices.
  • Operational Tooling: Licensing and integration of provisioning, monitoring, backup, and cybersecurity tools.

3. Operate Phase

The primary goal of the operate phase is to provide ongoing support, infrastructure management, change
management and the technical services necessary to run the application. There are several complex topics
that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • How should the SLAs be measured?
  • How to manage the changes?
  • How to automate and achieve operational efficiency?
  • How to manage security incidents and threats?
  • How to keep SAP applications up-to-date?
  • How to address capacity planning?

SAP Enterprise Cloud Services accelerates and simplifies customers‚Äô business transformation by running their SAP systems with a world-class level of availability, security and resilience, supported by an application-level SLA and a managed cloud service tailored to SAP systems. After a successful transition from the build phase to the operate phase, the ongoing support work is performed, along with additional application deployment activities. It covers the management of the installed infrastructure and applications, scaling the infrastructure, and managing ITIL processes through an engagement model with proven governance to secure business continuity.

  • Datacenter & Capacity Management: Continuous infrastructure optimization, backup integrity, and disaster recovery planning.
  • Security Operations: 24/7 threat detection, patching, vulnerability scanning, and advanced forensics.
  • Service Management: ITIL-based workflows, global support teams, and dedicated technical service managers ensure SLA adherence and business continuity.

Selecting the right deployment for your ERP system

Through SAP's Technical Assessment process, we work closely with each customer to address all questions related to the design, build, and operation of SAP in Cloud ERP Private. During this assessment, SAP provides detailed insights into the cloud service elements and explains the available options for transitioning to SAP Cloud ERP Private.

One such option is SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper, which helps customers extend support for their existing S/4HANA systems, ensuring business continuity: Bridging the gap with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper

SAP ECS empowers enterprises to move legacy ERP systems to private cloud environments without compromising control, compliance, or customisation. Our private cloud strategy serves as a blueprint for scalable, secure, and intelligent ERP modernisation.

entry.title: Re: Difference between TYPE and LIKE in ABAP ‚Äì When to us...
entry.content:
Typo in your answer: the "Comparison" array has "Feature / TYPE / LIKE" outside the array.

"Always use TYPE for work areas of tables (from DDIC)" is not clear, I guess it means "Always use TYPE for referring to DDIC types" (LIKE is still permitted with DDIC types in old ABAP code).

There are other variants of DATA keyword (TYPE TABLE OF, etc.) For more information, here are the direct links to ABAP documentation (latest ABAP version): DATA ... TYPE ... versus DATA ... LIKE ..., and TYPES ... TYPE ... versus TYPES ... LIKE ....

entry.title: Re: Managed RAP and errors (FAILED) from a determination.
entry.content: My understanding is that static variables should not be used for any "state" (e.g. "determination failed"), but the state should be stored in the CDS entity (as a dummy value or in a separate field). And the guiding principle was to keep modifying operations (including determinations) apart from validations, which are then executed on data that can no longer be changed (during the CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE phase).

entry.title: GL Planning in S4 Hana Fiori Launchpad:
entry.content:
GL Planning in S4 Hana Fiori Launchpad: 

In SAP S/4HANA, GL planning is performed through the Fiori Launchpad, offering a user-friendly and intuitive interface for financial planning activities.

Steps:

Configuration that is required for GL planning in SAP S/4HANA. Plan Category needed to be created in the system through SPRO Customizing. The configuration path is shown in the attached screenshot.

Create the Plan Category exactly as shown in the configuration screenshot below.

Next, access the Fiori Launchpad by entering transaction code ‚Äú/n/ui2/flp‚Äù and proceed to log in.

Then, navigate to the 'Import Financial Plan Data' tile within the Fiori Launchpad.

After selecting the tile, click on 'Download Templates' as shown in the screenshot, and download the template for 'P&L Statement Planning'.

Below is the attached GL planning template that needs to be filled out. If required, you can also add additional fields such as Profit Center and Cost Center by identifying the relevant field names from the following SAP help page: SAP Help ‚Äì Financial Plan Data Fields."

Once the template is filled with the required planning data, upload it using the same 'Import Financial Plan Data' tile in the Fiori Launchpad.

After uploading the file, navigate to the 'Display Financial Plan Data' tile to review the uploaded planning information.

 

 

After selecting the tile, enter the planning parameters as shown in the attached screenshot. Additionally, activate the navigation panel from the top left corner to include more parameter-based views, such as Profit Center, if it was included in your planning data.

 

 

To analyze Plan vs Actual data, you need to activate the 'P&L - Actual/Plan' tile in Fiori. This tile allows you to compare planned and actual figures at the Financial Statement Version (FSV) level, including its individual nodes, as shown in the screenshot below.

Summary: 
GL Planning in SAP S/4HANA, enabled through the Fiori Launchpad, provides a simple yet powerful approach for financial planners. From defining a plan category to importing data and analyzing plan vs. actual figures, the process is streamlined and user-friendly. With these capabilities, organizations can achieve better control and visibility over financial planning processes.

entry.title: Significant Performance Degradation on Depreciation Jobs After 2508 Release
entry.content:
Hello SAP , 

 

Issue Summary

 

Since the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition upgrade on August 18, 2025 (release 2508), we have observed a significant increase in execution times for Asset Accounting depreciation jobs triggered via the Schedule Asset Accounting Jobs tile.

 

All company codes are impacted, with processing times now much longer than before the upgrade. The duration depends on the number of fixed assets per company code: MDM SAS France, which has the largest asset volume, is the most affected.

 

Findings and Analysis



  • Before the upgrade (pre-18/08):



    • Full run for all company codes: approx. 20‚Äì30 minutes.



  • After the upgrade (post-18/08):



    • MDM France only: up to ~1h35‚Äì2h (ledgers 0L and 2L).
    • Other company codes: also impacted, with an increase proportional to asset volume.



  • Tests performed:



    • Comparison before/after on all company ‚Üí confirmed increase.
    • Job including all company codes (as in production) ‚Üí very high total duration.
    • Tests in quality environment, at two time slots:



      • Business hours (midday)
      • Off-hours (10 PM)
        ‚Üí Same result: processing time remains significantly higher than before the upgrade, regardless of schedule.





Business Impact



  • Delays in period-end closing and financial reporting.
  • Increased complexity in scheduling jobs, even during off-peak hours.



Environment Details



  • Product: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Release: 2508 (upgrade on 18/08/2025)
  • Applications:



    • Schedule Asset Accounting Jobs (F1914) ‚Äì job templates used:



      • Recalculate Depreciation
      • Depreciation Posting Run



    • Application Jobs ‚Äì monitoring and logs



  • Functional Area: FI-AA (Asset Accounting)
  • Impacted Company Codes: All 
  • Ledgers: 0L, 2L



Steps to Reproduce

  1. Open Schedule Asset Accounting Jobs .
  2. Run Recalculate Depreciation for a given period (e.g., August 2025) for a company code (e.g., MDM France).
  3. Then run Depreciation Posting Run for the same period.
  4. Check duration in Application Jobs.

 

Attachments Provided



  • Screenshots:



    • Processing times before upgrade
    • Processing times after upgrade



  • Excel file: comparison of durations by company code, ledger, and job type.
  • Job IDs and logs from Application Jobs.



Checks Already Performed



  • Ensured proper sequencing: Recalculate ‚Üí Posting.
  • Tested splitting by company code and staggering ledgers.
  • Tested during off-peak hours (10 PM) ‚Üí no improvement.
  • Confirmed that all company codes are impacted, with impact proportional to asset volume.



Expected Outcome



  • SAP analysis to confirm whether this is a performance regression introduced by release 2508.
  • Recommendations or fixes .



Best regards ,

entry.title: Installing GitHub Copilot in Eclipse ADT
entry.content:
Introduction

GitHub Copilot is an AI coding assistant platform that helps us while writing code by suggesting lines or blocks of code & troubleshooting them. This guide walks you through installing GitHub Copilot in Eclipse ADT (ABAP Development Tools).

Pre-requisites

  • Eclipse IDE with ADT installed

  • Existing Github account

Steps

  • Open Eclipse IDE and navigate to: Help - Eclipse Marketplace
     

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

  • Search & Select GitHub Copilot then install it by following the installation prompts.

  • Restart Eclipse
  • After restarting, Copilot is available in the menu bar. Sign in using Github account.

Using GitHub Copilot in Eclipse

  • Code Suggestions: Start typing your code. Copilot will automatically suggest completions. Press TAB to accept a suggestion.

  • Chat option: Use the Open Chat option to communicate with Copilot. We can also select the context/object for which we're asking questions or resolving errors.

Conclusion

After using it for few cases of RAP, I feel it needs to be evolve further for ABAP specific developments.  On the other hand the VSCode copilot extension works better for CAP developments in case of code suggestions & troubleshooting.

entry.title: SAP S/4 HANA Architecture Functional Flow
entry.content:
SAP S/4 HANA: -

SAP S/4 HANA is the latest version of SAP. The full form of SAP S/4 HANA is SAP Business Suite 4th generation ERP High Performance Analytic Appliance.
There are 3 layers that are present in SAP namely:-  
1. Presentation layer
2. Application Layer
3. Database Layer

In the 1990‚Äôs a new architecture was introduced, and it was R/3. In R/3 architecture we can observe the three layers namely presentation layer, application layer and database layer.

The speed of R/3 architecture is fast when compared with R/2 architecture. The algorithms in R/2 architecture were in the database layer whereas the algorithms in R/3 architecture are in the application layer. The database layer can be anyone like oracle, Microsoft etc...FIG : - R/3 Architecture

1. Presentation Layer:-
The presentation layer is a screen where user can interact with the system. For example we can take Monitor of a computer or laptop screen. So for SAP it is GUI --> Graphical User Interface. Here user will interact with SAP data base with the help of SAP GUI which is a software that will be installed on laptops.

2. Application Layer:-
This is the main advantage of SAP R/3 architecture. Here it acts as like middle wear between presentation layer and database layer. Here it will process the user input , applies business rules and execute the programs in this layer.
Here in this layer it will collects all the details or actions that are being carried out by the user and interacts with the database system and represents them on the output screen.

Dispatcher:- Dispatcher will collects the request and will decide which type of request it is whether it is dialog, update, background, spool , enqueue. After getting to know about the spool request type it will also check for the work processor which is idle.
Work Processor:- After getting the request into work processor it will co-ordinate with the database management and will perform the operation or action on the database and will also gets a acknowledgement .

3. Database layer:- 
After getting the request or command form the database management the database layer will process it and will update the request.

The below diagram is the in-depth process of how the database layer will function.

DATABASE LAYER FUNCTION FLOW: - 

  • The request from the work processor will first enter into the session manager and the session manager will makes user to automatic behaviour and transaction isolation level.
  • Once the request got established the request moves to the planning engine which analyses SQL.
  • And here SQL engine will runs the machine.
  • The transaction manager assigns a transaction ID and ensures that every operation follows the principle, transactions to the SQL engine and data engine.
  • The data engine takes over the user request and performs it on the database.
  • Index Server ‚Üí Executes SQL/MDX queries, does actual processing.
  • Name Server ‚Üí Knows where the data lives.
  • Pre-processor ‚Üí Text & search.
  • XS Engine ‚Üí Application services.
  • Persistence Layer ‚Üí Save points + logs.

In 2015 the SAP S/4 HANA has been introduced and here the database is HANA, and this is SAP‚ÄôS own database. The Hana database can also be called as in-memory database.

S/4 HANA is also called 4th generation SAP.

Versions of SAP S/4 HANA are released in the following years: -

VERSION                                                                                                             YY MM

1st Version of SAP S/4 HANA                                                                        1511(2015 11th)

2nd Version of SAP S/4 HANA                                                                       1610 (2016 10th)

3rd Version of SAP S/4 HANA                                                                        1709(2019 9th)

4th Version of SAP S/4 HANA                                                                        1809 (2018 9th)

5th Version of SAP S/4 HANA                                                                        1909(2019 9th)

6th Version of SAP S/4 HANA                                                                        2020 (YYYY)

7th Version of SAP S/4 HANA                                                                        2021(YYYY)

8th Version of SAP S/4 HANA                                                                        2022(YYYY)

9th Version of SAP S/4 HANA                                                                        2023(YYYY)

SAP S/4 Hana works with Fiori NetWeaver GUI.

Advantages of sap s/4hana:

  • The performance and speed have been improved due to databases.
  • Embedded analytics have been embedded in sap s/4hana
  • In ECC we can only perform operations, and some extract basic reports can be extracted in ECC, but not more complex reports can be extracted, when it comes to s/4 Hana we can easily extract the complex reports easily.

OLTP ‚Äì Online Transaction processing (ECC)

OLAP ‚Äì Online Analytical Processing (BI/BW)

OLTP + OLAP + Planning ‚Äì SAP S/4 HANA

Planning ->

  • MRP line
  • PD MRP
  • ATP (advanced available to promise)
  • PDS (production planning and detailed scheduling)

SAP HANA: -

     This Hana is a database which is also called an in-memory database, and this provides or is capable of analytics, data models and library for code writing.

The HANA database can be accessed through HANA STUDIO.

SAP HANA: -

     This Hana is a database which is also called an in-memory database, and this provides or is capable of analytics, data models and library for code writing.

The HANA database can be accessed through HANA STUDIO.

SAP BW powered by HANA (BW for HANA): -

SIDE CAR: -

                        For suppose you have an ECC system which is working on any database and now you want to connect it with the HANA database then there will be a middle wear SLT which is a software brings the data from table to HANA database.

 

  • HANA live is a tool which can be used to view the analytics of data.
  • Lumera system is a toll which is being used to represent or visualize the analytical data.

Benefits of a side car: -

  • Main cars are not being distributed.
  • It can be implemented in 1.5 to 2 months.

Drawback: -

  • Data footprint increases: - the data is being replicated from the production system to the side car so more space will be occupied.
  • The landscape is very complex.

SAP BW POWERED BY HANA: -
 It was introduced in 2012 and here the analytical can be obtained. The complex reports can be fetched within seconds only.

SAP BUSINESS SUIT POWERED BY SAP HANA: -
It was introduced in 2013 in this enhancement pack (EHP 7 or and here the system is ECC, and the database is HANA.)

OLAP + OLTP.

SAP SIMPLE FINANCE POWERED BY SAP HANA: -
ECC with HANA Database but the difference between this and SOH is only the fico module as they have simplified the data module for FICO and introduced Fiori apps separately for fico and ACDOCA table which is single source of truth table.

Apart from fico modules the other modules will work as they were functioning in the same manner as ECC on any other database.

S/4 HANA: -
This was introduced in 2015 they have simplified the data model for all the modules. They have introduced MATDOC, ACDOCA table and innovations + Fiori apps for all the modules

APP_L -> Technical application for ECC.

S/4 core -> Technical application for HANA.

So the above blog is a synopsis of how the 3 tier architecture will co ordinate with each other and performs the actions.

Feel free to comment.

Regards,
Neeraj.

entry.title: Email Notification to Approvers After Purchase Order Creation in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Flexible Workflow framework is widely used to manage approval processes for business documents such as purchase requisitions, purchase orders, and supplier invoices. By default, approvers receive workflow notifications directly in their Fiori Launchpad inbox. 

While this works seamlessly within the system, many organizations also expect approvers to receive an email notification in addition to the in-app notification. This ensures that:

  • Approvers are alerted even when they are not logged in to SAP.
  • Important purchasing decisions are not delayed.
  • The workflow process remains transparent and efficient.

To meet this requirement, SAP provides standard tools such as Workflow Scenario Management, Email Templates, and Email Transmission Monitoring. These enable businesses to configure and send customized email notifications for workflow tasks like purchase order approvals.

In the following blog, I will walk through a simple scenario where an approver receives an email notification after the creation of a purchase order.

Applications Involved:

Manage Workflow Scenarios

Maintain Email Templates 

Monitor Email Transmission

Step-by-Step Process

Step 1: Identify the Workflow Task

Why: This app helps us find the workflow task ID linked to the purchase order approval process. Without identifying the correct task, we cannot map the notification to the right workflow step.
What you‚Äôll do: Open the workflow scenario for Purchase Orders and note the task ID to be used.

how you‚Äôll do:

  • Open the Manage Workflow Scenarios app.
  • Select the relevant workflow (in this case, Purchase Order Flexible Workflow).
  • Identify the Task ID that is triggered when a PO is sent for approval.

Step 2: Maintain the Email Template

Why: SAP delivers standard templates, but they are generic. We often need to customize the subject and body of the email with business-specific content (e.g., PO number, company code, approver details).
What you‚Äôll do: Copy the pre-delivered template SWF_CRT_NOTIFY_RECIPIENTS, rename it as per your scenario, and adjust the subject/body with standard fields.

how you‚Äôll do:

  • Go to the Maintain Email Templates app.
  • Search for the pre-delivered template:
     SWF_CRT_NOTIFY_RECIPIENTS

  • Copy this template and create your own version.
    • Suggested naming convention: <ScenarioID>_CRT_ALL

  • Modify the Subject and Body as per business requirements, using the available standard data fields.

Step 3: Trigger the Notification

Why: To test the configuration, you need to trigger a purchase order approval workflow. This ensures the system sends both the in-app notification and the newly configured email notification.
What you‚Äôll do: Create a purchase order with a flexible workflow enabled and check whether the approver receives the email.

how you‚Äôll do:

  • Create a Purchase Order and ensure Workflow process is enabled and approver mail-id available.
  • At every approval level, the approver will now receive:
    • A system notification in SAP Fiori, and
    • An email notification delivered to their inbox.

Step 4: Monitor Email Transmission

Why: Sometimes emails fail due to configuration issues or missing recipient details. This app helps track and troubleshoot all outbound email notifications triggered from SAP.
What you‚Äôll do: Open the app to review email logs and confirm if the notification was successfully delivered to the approver.

how you‚Äôll do:

  • Use the Monitor Email Transmission app.
  • Here, you can check whether the email was successfully triggered and delivered.
  • This app provides details of all outbound email activities, helping administrators track and troubleshoot.

Summary

With just a few simple steps ‚Äî identifying the workflow task, maintaining an email template, and monitoring the transmission ‚Äî organizations can ensure that approvers are notified both inside SAP and via email. This enhancement improves workflow efficiency, reduces approval delays, and provides a better user experience.

Useful SAP notes:

3395242 - Approval/Rejection notifications are not sent for Purchase Contract workflows

Regards,

Vinith K

entry.title: Feedback on Joule
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community Members,

 

Recently, we have deployed Joule in our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. We found the performance is disappointing. Although we have raised several support tickets to SAP OSS, it is very time consuming (We have found a lot of issues, including transactional capabilities, navigational capabilities, and informational capabilities when testing it), and it seems currently there is no official way for us to share our feedback about Joule. (We cannot find Joule on the Customer Influence Portal)

 

The following are the issues of Joule‚Äôs navigational capabilities. 

Note: I have added all standard roles in IAS and suppose it is not an authorization issue.

 

Issue 1: Cannot provide Navigation Link

Please see the following surprising conversation with Joule.

We ask ‚ÄúFiori App to create PO‚Äù. Joule cannot provide the navigation link for such Fiori Apps.

When we ask ‚ÄúApp to create PO‚Äù, Joule can provide the navigation link.

 

Issue 2: Does not support GUI transactions

We understand that navigational capabilities only support Fiori Apps. However, I hope SAP Joule will provide navigation capabilities for GUI transactions in the future. Otherwise, we will face the following issue.

We ask ‚ÄúApp for Clearing Open Item Automatically‚Äù. Although no Fiori app is for F.13, it should not suggest F2223 (Reset Cleared Items)

It will only show the correct result if we ask for tcode.

Then we ask ‚ÄúApp for Open MM Period‚Äù Joule will provide irrelevant Fiori apps. including F2293 (Open FI Period) and F4684 (Open CO Period) when no Fiori app is for opening MM period. 

 

If we ask the same question again, Joule will provide a weird query to us

 

We have tested a lot of Joule‚Äôs Base capabilities. Most users feel frustrated with its performance. My comment is ‚ÄúJoule is a product with unlimited potential. However, currently it is still at an early stage.‚Äù I believe Joule will perform much and much better when our feedback can reach the SAP Joule Product Team.

 

Thanks for your reading, 

Chak

entry.title: Localization in SAP S/4HANA: Strategic Enabler or Deployment Bottleneck?
entry.content:
Localization is a foundational element in global SAP rollouts, and recognizing its importance early can significantly enhance deployment outcomes. It‚Äôs not just about translating interfaces or formatting currencies‚Äîit‚Äôs about aligning enterprise systems with country-specific legal, fiscal, and operational requirements. When overlooked, localization can become a deployment bottleneck, delaying go-lives and increasing compliance risks.

Key Localization Areas and Their Impacts

  1. Statutory Compliance

Governments mandate specific reporting formats such as SAF-T, e-invoicing, and VAT declarations. SAP S/4HANA must be configured to generate these outputs accurately and on time. Non-compliance can result in penalties or operational disruptions.

  1. Taxation and Financial Reporting

Localization affects tax codes, withholding tax logic, and financial statement structures. Country-specific requirements‚Äîlike India‚Äôs GST or Saudi Arabia‚Äôs einvoicing‚Äîrequire localized configurations across Finance, Procurement, and Sales modules.

  1. Payment and Banking Formats

Local banks often require country specific payment formats (e.g., ISO 20022, MT940, CNAB). These influence integration design and middleware configurations and can delay testing if not scoped early.

  1. Language Localization

Beyond translation, cultural nuances such as date formats, decimal separators, and naming conventions impact usability and data integrity‚Äîespecially in HR and Payroll modules.

  1. Legal Document Templates

Invoices, delivery notes, and contracts must meet local legal standards. SAP Smart Forms or Adobe Forms need to be customized per country, impacting development timelines and testing cycles.

  1. Master Data Localization

Country-specific fields (e.g., tax registration numbers, local address formats) must be embedded in master data models. This affects data migration, validation, and governance.

SAP‚Äôs Localization Toolkit

SAP supports localization through country versions, localization packs, and extensibility frameworks. The SAP Globalization Services offer Solutions, tools and content to meet local requirements. However, their effectiveness depends on early planning and sometimes cross-functional collaboration spanning across various modules.

Conclusion

Localization is not a technical detail‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategic enabler. Treating it as pivotal element in your implementations ensures smoother deployments, better compliance, and higher user adoption across geographies. Successful SAP programs embed localization into design workshops, testing cycles, and governance models from day one.

It is a strategic Enabler

When localization enables companies to:

  • Comply with local laws and regulations (e.g., tax, e-invoicing, statutory reporting).
  • Operate efficiently across geographies, adapting business processes to local norms.
  • Improve user adoption by aligning interfaces and workflows with local expectations.
  • Avoid legal and financial risks through accurate configuration of country-specific requirements.

It is a deployment Bottleneck

When localization is:

  • Underestimated or delayed, it can cause project overruns.
  • Treated as a post-go-live activity, it leads to rework and compliance gaps.
  • Not scoped properly, it affects integrations with local banks, tax authorities, and third-party systems.

References

üîπCountry / Region specific localization functions

  • Country/Region-Specific Functions | SAP Help Portal

üîπStatutory Compliance

  • SAF-T Overview ‚Äì SAP Help Portal
  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Overview
  • Statutory Reporting Process Overview

üîπPayment and Banking Formats

  • Country/Region-Specific Payment Format Mappings
  • Configuring Payment Medium Formats

üîπLanguage localization

  • Localization and Internationalization Framework (ABAP Cloud)

üîπCreating custom electronic document

  • Creating Custom Electronic Document in DRC

entry.content:
We are currently implementing the Sales module in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for a service company. The customer only works with service materials.

The sales process is as follows:

  • Sales Contract (quantity-based)

  • Sales Order

  • Preliminary Billing Document (Proforma)

  • Invoice

The customer does not work with billing plans.

The requirement is to trigger provisional revenue recognition when the Preliminary Billing Document (Proforma) is created, and then reverse this entry once the final invoice is posted. We are aware that the Proforma does not generate accounting postings, so most likely we will need to build something in SAP BTP.

 We are testing a scenario where we create a ‚Äúphantom goods issue‚Äù because revenue recognition is usually triggered at the goods issue confirmation.

  • We are using a non-stock material.

  • The sales order item category is TAX (non-stock).

  • Then we create and post an outbound delivery.

  • As a result, the system generates an Outbound Delivery Document and a Service Confirmation Document.

The issue:
We cannot find any way to track or display this Service Confirmation Document in the system. We would like to know:

  1. Does this Service Confirmation Document generate any accounting postings in Public Cloud?

  2. Where can this document be viewed or traced in the available Fiori apps?

Has anyone faced a similar requirement or can point us in the right direction?

Thanks in advance for your support!

entry.content:
Hello @Joey3 

Thanks for your follow-up

The cost element category
Is not exposed in any released CDS view or API within the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, therefore it cannot be utilised in custom logic. Instead, you might consider using the released semantics such as GLAccountType or IsPrimaryCostOrRevenueAccount from I_GLAccountInCompanyCode or I_GLAccountInChartOfAccounts.

Default account assignment (OKB9/TKA3A)
There is no released CDS/API for the data maintained in Manage Default Account Assignments (Config Activity 102639). For extraction and reporting purposes, rely on posting results, such as I_JournalEntryItem.Otherwise, consider using BAdi

SAP Useful References (Public Cloud):

  • SAP Help: G/L Master & Universal Journal concepts (released fields in G/L CDS)
  • SAP Help: Manage Default Account Assignments (Config Activity 102639)
  • SAP Help: Journal Entry Item CDS (posting-level reporting)

With best regards

entry.title: How CO-PA may help each level of Management
entry.content:
When we often hear about CO-PA we often think about complex reports that only finance teams may understand. However, it is one of the most powerful and probably one of the most underutilized report in an organization. Used properly, it can help bridge the gap between numbers and strategy wherein we are turning data into actual business insights.

CO-PA can be utilized by each level of management i.e. top, middle and lower. Below is an illustration on how each level of management can use this report to achieve their own goals.

 

Top-level management:

These are the strategists like CEO, CFO and Directors. Most important for them is to get a birds-eye view of the organization and are more concerned about future long-term strategies rather than daily operations. CO-PA helps answer questions like:

  • How does my profitability look across various regions/ customers/ product line?
  • Which product groups are driving our top-line and bottom-line and which are becoming costs to the company?
  • Which products should I scale up and which should I think about discontinuing?
  • Which market needs more penetration and which ones should I be exiting?
  • What are the true drivers of our profit?

 

Middle-level management:

These are people like zonal sales managers, plant heads etc. These people need on-ground data to plan and monitor targets set by the top-level management. They are also responsible for making top management‚Äôs vision a reality by taking into account on-ground challenges. CO-PA may help them to take corrective actions by giving answer to following questions:

  • Is there a sudden spike in material, logistics costs compared to previous period?
  • Are the actuals aligned with plan and standards set?
  • What is the status of contribution margin for each product compared to previous period?

 

Lower-level management:

These are team leaders, supervisors and managers. CO-PA can help them to answer:

  • How is my performance against daily/ weekly targets?
  • Are there any unusual cost trends?
  • What is the contribution margin for same product compared to previous period?

 

The questions I have provided are just an illustrative list. Each company can use CO-PA to build their own strategy and plan and monitor based on it.

entry.title: PY-ID: What is the change in Personal Income Tax of Indonesia (PPH21) from 2021 till now?
entry.content:
Since 2021, many legal changes have been released in Indonesian tax law. The most significant of these, which brought about widespread public awareness, was the Harmonization of Tax Regulations Law (UU HPP) in 2021. It aimed to simplify tax calculations. Following this, at the end of 2023, the government released Government Regulation No. 58 of 2023, which introduced a new calculation method and tax rate table. This marked the start of the TER method.

Before the TER method, both monthly and year-end taxes in Indonesia were calculated using progressive tax brackets (Tariff 17). With the TER method, monthly tax is now calculated using a TER tax rate, while the final year-end tax is still calculated using progressive rates.

The TER tax method officially took effect in 2024, marking its first tax year of use. This year, 2025, is its second. Furthermore, the Indonesian Directorate General of Tax (Direktorat Jenderal Pajak - DJP) has also implemented a new tax system called CoreTax. The DJP has updated its tax calculator to support the TER tax method, enabling us to perform our own tax calculations.

To ensure that your payroll system is up to date for the Indonesia TER tax method, please refer to the following KBA3347340. This KBA contains all the mandatory updates for the TER tax method. Once your system is fully updated, you can perform the monthly tax calculation using the TER tax rate. Please note that the final annual tax calculation (for the last tax period) will still be based on Tariff 17.

Following up on the overview I presented at the beginning of 2024, the presentation deck and a recording are available for your reference on Workzone Indonesia - Human Capital Management Localization. 

Please be aware of a significant change for 2025 regarding how tax information is submitted to the DJP. In 2024, submissions were made to the e-BUPOT system using an Excel file format. As of 2025, the file format has changed to XML and must be submitted through the e-BUPOT system within the CoreTax platform.

 

For details on the updated submission solution, please refer to the solution provided in the Regulatory Change Manager portal at this URL. 

How can we verify the accuracy of our tax results?

Start the verification from the basic case as a permanent employee receive only monthly salary (gross or regular income only).

Example: Mr. A, a permanent employee at Company XYZ, has a monthly salary of IDR10,000,000.00 in 2025. He is married with no dependents (PTKP K/0).

In the payroll log, you will see the tax method is "TER". TER Type is determined by the employee's PTKP status and is categorized as A, B or C. For example, Mr. A (PTKP K/0) would fall under TER Type A or TER Tax table A, and the specific tax rate will be based on which range of TER Tax table his salary falls into. You can verify your tax results by using the DJP tax calculator.

Monthly Tax Period, except last tax period.

Last Tax Period

Terminology

  • PPH21 - Pajak Penghasilan Pasal 21, is the personal income tax in Indonesia. This tax is applied to Indonesian residents and expatriates who resided in Indonesia for more than 180 days within any 12-month period.
  • TER - Tarif Efektif Rata-Rata, it is a single, effective rate to calculate tax on an employee's gross monthly income from January to November.
  • The Final Annual Tax, or the tax for the last period, is still calculated using the progressive tax brackets (Article 17) to ensure accuracy.

entry.title: Deprecation of API Basic Authentication & Configuring Open ID Connect
entry.content:
Understanding OpenID Connect (OIDC) in SuccessFactors with Identity Authentication Service (IAS)

In SuccessFactors and IAS (Identity Authentication Service), OIDC has replaced the older Basic Authentication model. With Basic Authentication, every API call carried a username and password. It was simple but highly insecure because those credentials could be intercepted or reused indefinitely. OIDC, by contrast, replaces static credentials with short-lived, digitally signed tokens. These tokens, usually in the form of JSON Web Tokens (JWT), are generated by IAS after a proper authentication flow and then used to prove both identity and authorization when calling SuccessFactors APIs.

The way this works is that any application or middleware that needs to call SuccessFactors first registers itself in IAS as a trusted client. IAS then issues that application a client ID and a client secret. When the application needs to call an API, it does not directly pass usernames or passwords. Instead, it requests a token from IAS using its client credentials. IAS verifies this request and returns an access token, and in many cases an ID token as well. The access token is then attached to the API call in the authorization header. SuccessFactors checks the validity of this token against IAS, and if the token is still valid and has the right scope, the API call is processed.

The security advantage here is that the tokens are short-lived, often valid only for minutes or hours. Even if someone managed to intercept them, their usefulness would be very limited. On top of that, IAS can enforce security policies like multifactor authentication, conditional access, or centralized identity checks before it ever issues a token. All of this dramatically reduces the risk of unauthorized access compared to Basic Authentication.

Pre-Requisites For Configuring OIDC

  1. Admin access of Security Centre to configure OIDC Client Application in Manage OIDC OAuth Client Application on SuccessFactors.
  2. Admin access of Identity Authentication Services for configuring OIDC on IAS end in Applications under Applications & Resources.
  3. OIDC must be enabled in IAS tenant and propagated to the SuccessFactors tenant that is linked to IAS, we can verify this by clicking  SuccessFactors tenant. The protocol type shall be SAML 2.0 & OpenID Connect and it should display a message above, like in the picture below.

Configuration Steps of Open ID Connect In Identity Authentication Services (IAS):

  1. For the very first step, login to IAS tenant and select Applications under Applications & Resources. Register OIDC Application by selecting Create. Select a display name of application and select OpenID Connect in the protocol type, rest of the selections are optional.


  2. Now go to Provided APIs under Application APIs  of recently created OIDC Application and enable the check for Allow all APIs for principal propagation.


  3. Now navigate to Trust>Single Sign-On and under that option access OpenID Connect Configuration.
    ‚Ä¢ Provide Name for a configuration as this is the mandatory field.
    ‚Ä¢ Scroll down to Grant Types and enable the check for Token Exchange (RFC 8693)
    ‚Ä¢ The checked boxes enabled here will be the required attributes during API authentication.
  4. We can further alter the validity of access tokens, refresh tokens and even control the maximum sessions per user from Token Policy (Custom) in OpenID Configuration.


  5. Now under Advanced Settings select JSON Web Token in Access Token Format.


  6. Now navigate to Dependencies under Application APIs. (The dependency name described here will be used later in the API call)
    ‚Ä¢ For Application, select SuccessFactors Tenant and the rest of the configuration will remain the same as below.


  7. Now go to Client Authentication under Application APIs to get the Client ID and Client Secret for using it in API authentication later.
    Upon saving a pop-up will appear with a system generated Client ID and Client Secret, copy and save for using it later.


  8. We can also copy our Client ID by scrolling top on the same screen.

Configuration Steps of Open ID Connect In SuccessFactors:

  1. Access Security Centre on SuccessFactors and navigate to Manage OIDC OAuth Client Application.


  2. Register an application in Application Type by entering the name of application.


  3. Now map the newly created application on SuccessFactors with the one configured on Identity Authentication Services by navigating to Application Map screen.
    ‚Ä¢ Click on Register on the top right corner of the screen.
    ‚Ä¢ Provide an Application Map Name.
    ‚Ä¢ Provide a Client ID that we copied in step 6 in IAS.
    ‚Ä¢ Choose an Application Type from dropdown. (It will appear with the same name as we created in Step 2 above in SuccessFactors)
    ‚Ä¢ Click Save.


  4. We have now successfully configured OpenID Connect application on IAS and mapped it to SuccessFactors Tenant. Now we can run our test API through postman (in our case).

Initiating An API Call Using Postman:

  1. Open postman and using POST method paste the below API call.
    ‚Ä¢ https://<<Your IAS Tenant Here>>/oauth2/token
  2. In Header Section add following keys,
    ‚Ä¢ Accept - application/json
    ‚Ä¢ Content-Type - application/x-www-form-urlencoded


  3. In Body Select x-www-form-urlencoded and enter below keys,
    ‚Ä¢ client_id - The one we saved in Step 6 in IAS.
    ‚Ä¢ client_secret - The one we saved in Step 6 in IAS.
    ‚Ä¢ grant_type - password
    ‚Ä¢ username - The admin account of IAS (It should be synced in IAS and login name must be used)
    ‚Ä¢ password - Password of that user account in IAS
  4. Upon clicking Send an Access Token will be generated which will be used to authenticate an another API call. That API call will be used to connect SF.


  5. For the next API call, use the same API as step 1 using POST method with same headers keys but additional keys in Body (Assertion & Resource)
    ‚Ä¢ client_id - Same as step 3 above.
    ‚Ä¢ client_secret - Same as step 3 above.
    ‚Ä¢ grant_type - urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:jwt-bearer
    ‚Ä¢ assertion - the access token that was generated in the previous API call.
    ‚Ä¢ resource - urn:sap:identity:application:provider:name:<<Dependency Name in OIDC Application>>

  6. Upon pressing Send another access token will be generated which will be the final token for fetching results from SuccessFactors through an API.


  7. For the last step, use the GET commamd with your actual API (created through OData dictionary on SuccessFactors) along with Authorization as a Headers key and upon pressing Send API will generate the result.
    ‚Ä¢ Authorization - Bearer <<access token generated in previous step>>


  8. Incase we faced a Invalid Client or Client Locked error during any step in API calls, make sure to check the Client ID status in OIDC Client Authentication under Application APIs in IAS as the client might have been locked due to wrong login attempts through Postman.
    Change the status to unlock and attempt API call again.

Ending Note:

With the introduction of multiple access tokens alongside traditional username and password authentication, SAP has significantly strengthened the security framework for API interactions. This enhancement not only adds an extra layer of protection against unauthorized access but also streamlines the user experience for those accessing a wide range of data across systems.

Previously, maintaining secure API access often required manual intervention such as regularly updating passwords for technical users. This process was both time-consuming and prone to errors. Now, SAP‚Äôs approach allows for automatic management of token lifecycles, intelligently selecting expiry durations based on system needs and user roles. This reduces administrative overhead and ensures continuous, secure connectivity without disrupting workflows.

By automating token renewal and offering flexible authentication options, SAP has made it easier for developers and integration teams to maintain secure, scalable connections to enterprise data while adhering to modern security standards and compliance requirements.

entry.title: Managing Misconduct in SAP Successfactors : An MDF-Driven Approach
entry.content:
Introduction :
In this blog we will explore handling misconduct cases by creating a dedicated section in SAP Successfactors Employee Central, this section will help business take the right action based on based on structured inputs.

Context : 

A while ago a customer requested a section for Misconducts that will be visible for Managers and there is going to be a workflow for HR to approve of the misconduct to be applied on their direct reports.

Solution Overview :

An MDF to be Placed on People Profile that will generate Sanctions to be applied on employee based on Inputs done by Managers.

We will need 4 MDFs 

[1 for Misconduct Types , 2 will be a parent and child MDF essentially to work as a table that we will lookup upon, 1 Will be visible on the Employee Profile] 

Flow of the Process :

In my case it was the manager who initiates the sanctions, So once the manager selects the misconduct & Occurrence it will propagate sanctions to be applied on the employee and once save HR will choose to approve or decline.


Creating the MDFs :

1- Misconduct Types : This will be all Misconducts types in the business list plain and simple , we will create all of these misconducts via Import and export 
Example :
Type of a Misconduct

 
2- Now we will head to Parent & Child MDFs , Parent will be same as Misconduct type it will just work as a container of the upcoming mdf as it just feels better to keep track without modifying in the source so, Now in the Child Object 
we will create fields like [ Misconduct Types we will refer to the previous MDF we created in this one , 1st Time , 2nd , 3rd , 4th these fields depending on the business as it will contain the deduction amount/ or some might be just a warning] 

Example : 
Misconduct Details working as a Container for all types of Possible Misconduct and their Sanctions

 

 

We will Import Misconduct Details which is Misconduct Type & Sanctions to be applied for each occurrence.

3- MDF to be Visible in the People Profile :
This MDF will be placed in a section on People Profile ,but before that we need to set the business rule that will help the Manager choose the correct sanctions to be applied based on the Internal Policy we got.

I did make it on change and to be placed on a field in this MDF as per the customer desire you can make it on save.
Business Rule :

 

This will cover the 1st time ,so you will need to do the rest to cover all the sanctions.

Now this is how it's going to look like once manager chooses the inputs :

 
At the end once it's saved a workflow will be sent to HR to either approve / decline.

Conclusion : 

This setup is just the starting point for managing misconduct in a clear and consistent way in SuccessFactors. With a few MDFs, rules, and a workflow, managers can take action and HR can stay in control.

This is first step I'd say ? The next blog would be automating it so it posts directly the deduction in the Non Recurring Pay Component Section and make sure it's replicated to Payroll.

Thank you all for your time.
